The next figures show violin plots of each metric on the formality task, where each point is a metric for a singlex0x_{0}, demonstrating Qwen3-4B is the most controllable and faithful to the user request for this setting (cvg=1.0\mathrm{cvg}=1.0, medianMAE=0.09\mathrm{MAE}=0.09).

Notably, FLUX-s achieves a medianρ,R>0.9\rho,R>0.9and a medianMAE=3.52\mathrm{MAE}=3.52, showing a much better controllability and faithfulness than the rest.

Figure A.5:Requesting string length in{1​⋯​10}\{1\cdots 10\}with 5-shot prompting.We ask the LLM to generate a string of lengthNNcharacters, whereN∼Unif​{1​⋯​10}N\sim\text{Unif}\{1\cdots 10\}. The controllable set estimates are shown on the (right), with Gemma3-4B displaying the highestα\alpha-controllability (α=0.1\alpha=0.1), to 80% of the desired range. The distribution of string lengthsyTy_{T}is plotted with respect to the initial request on the (left). In general, especially for Qwen3-4B and Gemma3-4B, the generations are faithful to the request no matter the initial prompt, seen by points landing on the liney=xy=x(dashed). This is corroborated by the (middle) three plots, however, SmolLM3-3B shows high variance of the faithfulness metricsρ\rho,RR, and MAE across initial states.

Figure A.6:Requesting an average word length in[2.0,10.0][2.0,10.0]with 5-shot prompting.We ask the LLM to generate a sentence whose average word length is values in[2.0,10.0][2.0,10.0], up to an error ofγ=0.1\gamma=0.1, with 5 shots in the initial inputu0u_{0}. (Right) The controllable set estimates for all models. We find SmolLM3-3B and Qwen3-4B to be controllable only to a small fraction (0.18 and 0.07, respectively), and Gemma3-4B to a larger fraction (0.61), of requests. (Left) The final output distributionyTy_{T}is shown compared to the requested average word length; in general, models fail for larger requested lengths– interestingly, Qwen3-4B tended to resort to “default responses" such as “A cat sat on a mat" or “The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog." (Middle) The large spreads inρ\rho,RR, and MAE, where each point represents the metric computed for a single initial state, demonstrate a large sensitivity of model response to the initial state.

Figure A.7:Requesting an even/odd number with 5-shot prompting.We ask the LLM to generate a positive even or odd integer, with 5 shots in the initial inputu0u_{0}. (Left) We show the distribution of responses byt=5t=5turns, including an error category (righthand bars on each barchart), where the LLM response was not parse-able to an integer. The (middle) two plots show the LLM’s faithfulness to the request, where each point depicts the mean accuracy or F1 score of a given initial state’s reachable set. While (right) Qwen3-4B achieves perfect controllability of theα\alpha-controllable set (α=0.1\alpha=0.1) with these inputs, as well as perfect faithfulness to the request (middle), results for other models are sensitive to the initialx0x_{0}, seen by nonzero variance in the violin plots. Notably, near-perfect faithfulness does not necessarily imply controllability, seen SmolLM3-3B: while it achieves a high accuracy and F1 score to the request on average (middle), it isnotcontrollable for this task (right).

Figure A.8:Larger LLMs are more controllable and calibrated on string length.For Qwen3 sizes ranging from 0.6B to 14B (x-axis), we requested string lengths ranging in{1​⋯​10}\{1\cdots 10\}, with 0-shot prompting and 5 dialogue turns. Controllability (right) and calibration metrics (left) increase reliably up to 14B, though metrics (cvg,RR,ρ\rho) increase most drastically for smaller sizes (0.6B→\to1.7B) and appear to saturate for larger sizes.

Figure A.9:Larger LLMs are more controllable and calibrated on average word length.For Qwen3 sizes ranging from 0.6B to 14B (x-axis), we requested output text whose average word lengths range in[2.0,10.0][2.0,10.0], with 0-shot prompting and 5 dialogue turns. Controllability (right) and calibration metrics (left) increase up to 14B in a sudden phase transition at 4B where the model gains in performance.

Figure A.10:Requesting objects at specific locations to T2IMs.We query T2IM with the prompt “White background. [obj] at the [pos] of the image.”, wherepos∼Unif​(top left, top right, bottom left, bottom right, center)\texttt{pos}\sim\text{Unif}(\text{top left, top right, bottom left, bottom right, center}), for allobjin the 80 COCO classes. As measurement, we divide the image in a grid of3×33\times 3(each area of width and height13\frac{1}{3}rd of the image) and we use an object detector to determine if the object is in one of the requested areas. We observe that T2IM struggle at placing objects at specific locations, even in the simple setting provided. In the (left) figure we see that models tend to place objects in the center (Cin the x-axis), followed by bottom right and left (BR,BL) and finally top right and left (TR,TL). The darker lines are the count of objects not placed in any of these positions. The other plots show the averaged statistics per object, showing that FLUX-s is theoretically controllable (they reach the whole output space with maximal coverage and show better accuracy). However, these results are far from perfect controllability, underscoring the need for rigorous analysis of models.

Figure A.11:Requesting image saturation to T2IMs.We query T2IM with the prompt “Generate an image with [100×sat100\times\texttt{sat}]% saturation.”, wheresat∼Unif​[0,1.0]\texttt{sat}\sim\text{Unif}[0,1.0]. This is an example of quantized reachability, therefore we set aγ=0.1\gamma=0.1We observe that T2IM FLUX-s and SDXL are theoretically controllable (they reach the whole output space with maximal coverage). However, the models are not calibrated at all to the request, with correlations only reachingρ,R<0.1\rho,R<0.1. In the (right) plot we show the reachable sets for each input (dark bars) and the controllable set (shaded area). Interestingly, the models show a stark difference in terms of controllability in this setting.
Figure A.12:Extended controllability trajectories for deterministic LLMs.To supplementFig.˜2(top, middle), we show here the DP trajectories for the remaining LLM tasks, in the deterministic case.

Figure A.13:Controllability results, stochastic LLMs.For the formality task, average word length, string length, and even/odd number (top to bottom), we show the controllability summaries for stochastic systems. The sample complexities are the same as for the deterministic system, seeSec.˜5. Adding stochasticity due to sampling results in more diffuse distributions of the output (left), notably for the even/odd integer task, as well as worse faithfulness metrics, as expected.
